div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Spring begins to-day, and the conditions are as springlike as one could wish for. The weather is delightfully bright and cool, a light northerly breeze blowing. The past winter at Alexandria has been a dry one compared with 1908, the total rainfall for the season amounting to 7.02 inches, 89 against 11.22 inches in the previous season.

div.head: THE HELIOPOLIS OASIS.
div.p: Mr. Edward Dicey, C.B., contributes the following article to the "Daily Telegraph" :-

The Oasis City, the New Cairo In the desert is now in course of construction. When I visited it in the early part of last spring a few small sticks and stones stuck up in the sand of the Suez dosert were the only outward and visible signs of this huge enterprise, calculated, in my opinion, to change many of the conditions of life in Egypt--which, perhaps, at no distant period, may render the desert city a formidable rival to Kair el Masr (Cairo the Great), to use its Arabic title. When I stumbled over the sand some nine months ago, in company with one of the leading promoters of the scheme, when I learnt from bim the enormous proportions of the project, and when I ascertained the immense capital required for its execution, I confess I felt more than doubtful whether the Oasis City was ever likely to be more than a grandiose conception, which would, have to be abandoned as a practical impossibility. From the extraordinary progress made in less than a year's time towards its completion, I have no longer any doubt of the work being achieved. Whether, when completed, it will prove a success or a failure from a pecuniary point of view, is a question which the unknown future must decide, and concerning which my personal opinion would carry no weight or value.

In order, however, to render intelligible the circumstances under which the ideas of a huge suburb to Cairo in the desert came into existence, the difficulties the idea had to encounter before it could be contemplated as a serious proposal, and the progress that has already been made in carrying this gigantic scheme into effect, I will endeavour to narrate as briefly impossible the marvellous story of the Oasis City

Everybody interested in Egypt is familiar with the almost fantastic rise in the price of building sites in and about Cairo during the last few years. I fully admit that the suddenness and rapidity of this rise bear a suspicious resemblance to many building booms I have known of in other lands, which went up with a run and then came down with a smash. I confess I have thought month after month that the slump was impending, and month after month have been agreeably disappointed. I have at last come to the conclusion that the boom, though it may be--and, as I think, is--exaggerated by , reckless speculation, rests largely upon permanent causes. From the geographical configuration of Cairo the area of unoccupied building land is extremely limited. On the other hand, owing to the rapid increase of general prosperity under British rule, and, even more, to the high prices of the cotton crop, the staple product of Egyptian industry, the incomes of the landowning classes, from the Pashas down to the fellahs have become far larger than they were. With larger means, there has sprung up a sudden desire to have houses in the capital.

This demand for houses has been—and still is--extending, with the consequence that the demand exceeds the supply, and that though there may be a fall in the price of houses, this price is not at all likely to fall to the level of three or four years ago. Houses are daily being pulled down to be converted into flats, and the average rentals for offices or shops or apartments, not to mention private houses, have risen out of an proportion to the means of the poorer class of tenants and the lower ranks of the officials in the public service. As a rule, here, houses are let on short tenancies. The result is that leases are constantly terminating, and that the tenant has either to renew his lease on a largely-increased rental or to remove to inferior premises. The question of re-housing the poorer classes, and especially the poorer native officials, has been under discussion for some time. The Egyptian Government, acting as usual on the instructions of the British Agency, has done what it could to remedy this evil, and has increased the salaries of the higher officials, mostly of English birth and breeding, by assisting them to build villas at Ghezireh, but this reform does not improve the position of the poorer native officials, whose comparatively small salaries barely enable them to make both ends meet.

The grievance sustained by the humbler class of public servants owing to the extravagant price of house rent for themselves and their families appealed largely to the sympathies of certain enlightened members of the Egýptian community, and Boghos Pasha Nubar, the son and heir of the greatest of Egyptian statesmen since the days of Mahomet. Ali, was, if I am rightly informed; the first to realise that the best, if not the sole, remedy for the overcrowding of Cairo was to extend the town to the desert of Suez. The ideal was eagerly caught up by M. Empain, the well-known Franco-Belgian financier and the constructor of the underground railway, the " Metropolitain " of Paris, and the concessionaire of the Cairo electric tramways. To these two gentlemen belongs the credit of having believed in the possibility of creating a new and healthy town in the heart of a drý, barren, and sandy desert.

Their first step was to search for water in the Qasis which, as the site of the great ancient city of Heliopolis, must, it was reasonable to assume, have had running springs in its immediate vicinity. The Cairo Waterworks Company, the most successful enterprise in all Egypt, has been obliged recently to remove ite reservoirs from the western to the eastern bank of the Nile, because in its former situation the water of the river was suspected of being polluted by the sewage of the capital A subter. ranean stream of perfectly pure water had been discovered which, though running parallel to the Nile, had, it was imagined, issued from one of the equatorial lakes. It was not an unreasonable hypothesis that if there was one river which reached to the Mediterranean through the Nile Valley without mingling its waters with those of the Nile proper, similar streams might be found hard by any of the dead cities of the past, but though the syndicate of the Oasis Company bored on every side of Heliopolis to a depth of 180ft, they found no trice of any other subterranean rivers in the Suez desert. It was useless to bore beyond this depth, as the cost of raising the water by machinery above this height would have been absolutely prohibitive. Soon afterwards, how. ever, it was discovered that the volume of water in the subterranean river, by which the waterworks of Cairo have been supplied for the last twelve months, was so ample that it could well afford to provide water for the new Cairo in the desert.

The grievance sustained by the humbler class of public servants owing to the extravagant price of house rent for themselves and their families appealed largely to the sympathies of certain enlightened members of the Egýptian community, and Boghos Pasha Nubar, the son and heir of the greatest of Egyptian statesmen since the days of Mahomet. Ali, was, if I am rightly informed; the first to realise that the best, if not the sole, remedy for the overcrowding of Cairo was to extend the town to the desert of Suez. The ideal was eagerly caught up by M. Empain, the well-known Franco-Belgian financier and the constructor of the underground railway, the " Metropolitain " of Paris, and the concessionaire of the Cairo electric tramways. To these two gentlemen belongs the credit of having believed in the possibility of creating a new and healthy town in the heart of a drý, barren, and sandy desert.

div.p: This bank has finished the installation of a safe deposit and strong rooms at its Cairo branch in Midan Suares.

div.head: Coptic Schools
div.p: The Government has decided, beginning from 1908, to give an annual grant to the industrial school which the Copts are constructing at Cairo.

div.head: Syrians and the University.
div.p: The leading members of the Syrian colony of Cairo will meet on Saturday next to decide what attitude they will adopt towards the Egyptian University.

div.head: Coast-Guard Administration.
div.p: The contract for the construction of a steam tug boat for this administration has been adjudicated to Messrs. P. McGregor & Sons, Kirkintilloch, Scotland, for the sum of £3,130.

div.head: Mouses for Government Employee.
div.p: The Public Works Ministry has instructed M Paul Conin-Pastour, inspector in the State Buildings Service, to draw up plans of houses to be built for Government servants on the land of the Abbassieh Oasis Company.

div.head: The Rotations.
div.p: The usual summer rotations will commence in the 4th Circle of Irrigation, Minieh and Beni Souef Provinces, on April 1st. Particulars of the periods of stopping and working will be issued by the Inspector of Irrigation through the Mudiriehs.

div.head: The Grandmoulin Affair.
div.p: According to "Al Akhbar" Mustapha Pasha Kamel was summoned by the Parquet General on Tuesday last in order to attend an enquiry into the circumstances of his alleged pewspaper libel of M Grandmoulin. The Pasha stated that he only published a letter from the Omdeh of Warrak.

div.head: The Arab Character.
div.p: Mr. Mark Sykes delivered a lecture last week to the Royal Geographical Society on his journey in North Mesopotamia, the region between the rivers Tigris and Euphrates. The rules of war, he said, were as atrictly and decently observed among Arabs as by the white and red knights in "Alice in Wonderland." To kill an enemy in battle was discreditable and savage; to wound slightly was what was aimed at, and to wound a man slightly with a bamboo lance 20 feet long was no small feat of skill To surrender was not discreditable; flight was as justifiable as attack ; to carry on warfare at night would be scandalous and shameful, or productive of inconvenient reprisals. Camps were practically out of bounds for a similar reason.

div.head: Earthquakes Recorded at Helouan.
div.p: No less than thirty-nine earthquakes were noticed at Helouan from March 30 to December 26, 1904. They were registered by Milne's Seismograph at Helouan Observatory. The observations are given in the report, which has just been published, containing the routine observations made at the new Observatory during 1904. Various causes have contributed to the delay in publishing this report, and it is hoped that that for 1905 will be published very shortly, and the one for 1906 9 months after the end of the year. Some contributions to the discussion of the climate at Helonan and Abbassieh are ready for publication but it has been deemed best to defer these till the publication of the above reports, so that this report may be delayed no further.

div.head: AMATEUR THEATRICALS AT MUSTAPHA.
div.p: The little theatre at Mustapha Pasha last night was filled with a large and fashionable audience to witness the performance of "Our Boys," a comedy in three acts, by some local amateurs in aid of the Soldiers' and Sailors' Families Association. Outward evidence of the fashionable gathering inside was afforded by the large number of motor-cars which were ranged outside the theatre, while inside the pretty toilettes of the ladies, interspersed by the bright uniforms of the officers of the Dublin Fusiliers, afforded a brilliant scene.

The plot of "Our Boys" hinges on the complications arising from the two "eligible" sons of, in the one case Sir Geoffrey Champneys, a county maguate, and in the other Perkyn Middlewick, a "retired butterman," becoming infatuated, in direct opposition to their respective sire's wishes, to two charming young ladies, one Violet Melrose, an heiress, and the other Mary Melrose, her poor cousin. As might be expected, the Baronet desires his son Talbot to make a good match and therefore formally choose the haughty heiress, who by the way is antagonistic to the butterman, the latter favouring her poorer and less haughty cousin. Judge therefore the anger of their respective parents when the drawling, empty-headed, young Champneys(well acted by Mr. Macauase) singles out Mary Melrose, wane the debonair, son of Middlewick (Mr. Hewitt) falls head over heels in love with her rich cousin.

The whole play is very amusing, much of the fun being due to the illiterate butterman, admirably noted by Mr. Chataway. Mr. Preston takes the part of Sir Geoffrey very well, Miss MacCallum and Miss Graves making two charming consins. Mention must also be made of Mrs. Borton as Clarrissa Chainpneys, Sir Geoffrey's sister, and Miss Mallon as Belinda, the lodging house slavery.
Another performance will be given this evening, when it is anticipated a large audience will be present.

div.head:
AMERICAN MONEY MARKET.
THE CRISIS RELIEVED.
div.p: Fop the first time' since the present crisis commenced the conditions in New York seemed to improve yesterday. Despite the irregularity of the quotations, the London market generally has exhibited a better tone.

div.head: FATHY BEY'S APPOINTMENT.
SIR E. GREY'S DEFENCE OF LORD CROMER.
div.p: The questions put to Sir Edward Grey by Mr. Dillon in the House of Commons last week, regarding the appointment of Fathy Bey Zagloul as Under-Secretary at the Ministry of Justice, were as follows:

Mr. Dillon sked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether Fathy Bey Zagloul, who acted as Judge in the Denshawi trial, had been appointed Under-Secretary at the Ministry of Justice; whether the British representative in Egypt was in any way consulted in reference to the appointment; and whether the Prime Minister and the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs had received any protests from Egypt against this appointment.

Sir E. Grey (Northumberland. Berwick). — I have received one protest against the appointment purporting to be signed by 31 persons. For the rest, I can only refer to my previous answer, to the effect that I had no information, and it was not a matter in which his Majesty's Government should interfere.

Mr Dillon asked whether his Majesty's representative in, Egypt was consulted in regard to all these appointments; and whether the right hon. gentleman's attention bad been directed to the extremely serious effect on public opinion in Egypt of the promotion of this judge so soon after the trial.
Sir E. Grey.--This is a point on which I have perfect confidence in the discretion or his Majesty's representative. (Opposition cheers )

Mr. Dillon said that perhaps the right hon. gentleman would be good enough to answer the question whether his Majesty's representative in Egypt was not, as a matter of fact, consulted with regard to all these appointments.

Sir E. Grey -I cannot say whether he is consulted in regard to all these appointments. Very likely he is consulted in regard to most of them, and, if so, I have no intention whatever of questioning the conclusion to which he comes. (Opposition cheers.)

div.head: SALE OF PRINCE IBRAHIM'S STABLE.
div.p: The sale of the stables of the late Prince Mohamed Ibrahim, which took place last week at Cheri's, rue de Ponthieu, Paris, was a great success, there being a large crowd of buyers present and some good prices being realised. Bidding was very brisk The pair of bays, Empress and Bonfire, were knocked down for 9,500 frs. to M. de Roosen, who also bought Warwick for 2,600 frs. and Interview for 4,400 frs. Count Léautaud purchased Violet at 1,900 frs, and Lily at 2,500 frs. The fine chestnut horse French went to M. Léon Thome at the price of 3,800 frs and Rover at 3,600 frs. Rambler was knocked down to M. Hawos for 1,600 frs, and Wonder to M. Firmin-Didot for 1,900francs.

The polo ponies fetched good prices. Daly was bought for Princess Ibrahim. Prince Radziwill acquired Three Cheers for 3,000 frs. and Mr. Dooley for 1,800 frg. Bonbon went to M. G. Menier for 3,000 frs and Greyling to M. Harjes for 1000 frs.
The thoroughbred colt by Fou-rire was bought for 2,625 frs. by the trainer W. Flatman.
The late Prince's carriages and harness also fetched very good prices.

div.head: THE HIGH PRICE OF EGYPTIAN YARNS.
div.p: Mr. W Tattersall states in the "Financier" that Egyptian yarns as made in Bolton and district are getting dearer and dearer. With each further advance in the raw material spinners have put up quotations, and, owing to their strong position, full rates have been held for. Prices all round are exceedingly high, and - users report that it is impossible to purchase such qualities tollay and produce cloth at a profit . The consumption, however, of the finer numbers in cotton yarns has considerably increased during the last year or two outside Lancashire, and for certain districts of Yorkshire a good business can now be done. The lace trade in, Nottingham is also an active buyer, and prosperity there means increased work for producers in Bolton and district. The finer numbers in weft are scarce,and users who are underbought are awkwardly situated at a time like the present Combed descriptions are decidedly strong, and carded counts are also very deeply under contract.

div.head:
ASSOUAN DAM TO BE RAISED.
MINISTERIAL DECISION TO-DAY.
div.p: "The Council of Ministers has to-day decided that the Assouan Dam shall be raised so as to store water to a level seven metres (23 feet) above the present maximum.

This decision has only been arrived at after an exhaustive survey of the Nile Valley between Wady Halfa and Khartoum has proved that no suitable site for the construction of a dam of the size required and a reservoir of the necessary capacity exists on the river channel between these two places. Consequently, the only alternative is to raise the Assouan Dam.
The quantity of water thus stored will be more than 2½ times that impounded in the existing reservoir. This will afford sufficient water in summer for the irrigation of about -one million acres.
There are at present some 950,000 acres of waste land in the southern tracts of Egypt, and it is proposed to make use of the extra water for their irrigation.

The increase of the wealth of Egypt brought about by the realisation of this project will be very considerable The Government will reap the benefit of the sale of these lands and the taxes imposed on them, after they have been brought under cultivation. The landowners will gain by the large increase of the cotton crop, which is estimated at from 3½ to 4 million Egyptian pounds.

With regard to the regrettable necessity imposed on the Government, namely, the further subinergence of the Philæ temples and the flooding of certain other Nubian monuments, it is intended to use all possible moans to minimise the injury thus caused. An archælogical survey of Nubia will be taken in hand and a minute record made of every monument situated between Wady Halfa and Assouan. The temples affected by the water will be consolidated as far as possible, and the different archäological societies will be asked to co-operate in this work.
The cost of the raising of the dam is estimated at L.E. 1,500,000.

div.head: STEAMER ASHORE IN CANAL.
INTERRUPTION TO TRAFFIC.
div.p: The Dutch mailboat Rindjani has been badly ashore in the canal, in the small lake, since yesterday morning. Traffic has consequently been stopped Numero 18 steamers, including the P. and O. mailboat China, are unable to pass.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.

His Highness has signified his intention of being present at Abbassieh.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: The Council of Ministers met at 11 o'clock this morning under the presidency of H.E. Mustapha Pasha Fehmy.

div.head: INTERESTING ECCLESIASTICAL APPOINTMENT.
div.p: The Rev Constantine Pagonis, Chief Archdeacon of the Greek Orthodox Patriarchate of Alexandria, has been appointed Vicar of the Greek Church in London. On Sunday next His Holiness Mgr. Photius I , Greek Orthodox Patriarch of Alexandria, Lybia, Pentapolis, Ethiopia, and of All Egypt, will formally ordain the Archdeacon ag Archimandrite. The Rev. Constantine Pagonis will subsequently leave immediately for England so as to be able to officiate at the Orthodox Church in London on the Greek Easter.

div.head: CAIRO KHEDIVIAL CLUB.
div.p: A Cairo contemporary announced a short time back that the committee of the above club had leaged for a number of year the premises at present occupied by the Sucreries et Raffineries d'Egypte at Bab-el-Louk, to which the club would be transferred. This rumour is incorrect inasmuch as no decision has yet been arrived at, and none is expected before at least two or three months, when the sub-committee appointed for the purpose will meet to decide the question of the eventual transfer.

It should be remembered that the Société du Club Khedivial du Caire, which was constituted in 1884 and all the shares of which are held solely by the members, was for a term of 25 years, consequently the committee have ample time yet, about two years wherein to consider the several offers that have been made for housing the club when the above term expires The property in the Sharia El Manakh is a very valuable one, and from the proceeds when sold the society expects to be able to build handsome new premises and divide a large surplus among the members in 1909.

div.head: MEDITERRANEAN COMMAND.
CO-ORDINATION SCHEME.
div.p: The alteration in the status of the military commands in the Mediterranean, which takes place this year, will result in the complete co-ordination under one General of the work of the troops in Egypt, Cyprus, Crote, and at Malta and Gibraltar.

Hitherto the three big commands named bave had separate existence, with only such coordination as might be obtained from time to time under War Office direction. As this is not a desirable state of things, in view of war conditions, the whole of the Mediterranean garrisons will, as announced by Mr. Haldane, come under the control of a single commander-in-chief.

In a military sense, the situation in the Mediterranean has altered considerably in recent years, and the protection of Egypt, both internally and on its land frontier across the Suez Canal, is an added problem to the military measures for safeguarding the Canal and the overland route to the Red Sea. It is de-airable that the administration, preparation, and reinforcement of Egypt or India from the Mediterranean should be placed in the hands of one controlling general, and not remain, as now, a scattered responsibility.

The creation of a commander-in-chief for the Mediterranean gives to the Army an appointment which, in a measure, will compensate for the abolition of the Commandership in-Chief of the Army At present (excluding the Indian command) there exists no field cominand under the Army Council, except South Africa, to which'a senior general can be sint after service at headquarters, or command ing at Aldershot, or in Ireland ; the now appointment, with headquarters at Malta, will create a post second only to India in strategic importance. The Mediterranean general's pay of £5000 per annum is less by some £1600 than the total amount drawn by the Commander-in-Chief in India, but it is greater than any of the home posts. The General Commanding-in Chief at Aldershot receives £3000, the General in Ireland £3000 and allowances, the Inspector-General of the Forces £4000, and the Chief of the General Staff 23000. The Commander-in-Chief in South Africa receives £4000.
The holder of the new post will not have any civil duties of governorship, and he will co-ordinate the work of the three separate commands into one whole for war purposes.
The strength of the combined command will be as follows :-
Malta (including Creto)............. 7500
Gibraltar .....3800
Oyprus.....120
17,120 At Gibraltar there will be two line battalions instead of three, and at Malta five instead of seven.

div.head: PIANOFORTE RECITAL.
div.p: Signor Angelelli's piano recital on Wednesday afternoon at the Savoy Hotel was fairly well attended, and was, indeed, quite worth hearing. He had a well-chosen programme calculated to show to advantage his delicate touch and refined interpretation Signor Angelelli is by no means an impressive or forcible pianist ; he would make little enough of the greater Beethovens, Bach, or some of the more formidable Chopins. Schumann's Novelette, the two middle movements of the Grieg Sonata (especially the menuet), Goldmark's Paysage, and the two Schutte pieces really were suited to his abilities, as was the Scarlatti (Pastorale e Capriccio), and he played them very prettily. The Goldmark "Paysage" is a most charming, subdued, and suggestive little composition, and the Schutto Romance and "Etude Mignonne" are both most pleasing. He played Chopin's Nocturne in D flat well, but the ballade that followed did not suit him : it should have far more force, especially in its 2nd theme, when one is expectant, then carried away with a quick excited flight of released notes. That effect be entirely missed ; in fact both the Chopin pieces, and perhaps the Bach-Saint Saens (though that combination is rather unsatisfactory, would have sounded well in a Final room. The Sgambati Prelude and pugue is very pretty and old-fashioned, not at all severe but well defined and carefully connected all through : that he played quite well. He is, in a sense, a miniature pianist, and as long as he keeps away from the great works he is well worth hearing,.

div.head: COMMISSION MUNICIPALE.
ADMISSION DE LA PRESSE.
div.p: (Compte-Rendu de notre représentant) La Commission Municipale s'est réunie hier à 4 h. 1/2 de l'après-midi sous la présidence du Dr Schiess Pacha.

Comme la presse était pour la première fois admise aux séances, le présidenti a lu aux journalistes présents quelques mots de bien venue. Nous profitons de cette circonstance pour f liciter M. Michel Salvago d'avoir proposé cette innovation et, plus heureux que ses prédécesseurs, d'avoir su la faire accepter par ses collègues. Les critiques et observations des journaux seront, en effet, d'un grand profit pour la ville et pour les conseillers municipaux eux-mêmes. Inatile de dire que pour notre part, contrairement aux habitudes municipales, nous passerons rapidement sur les questions d'ordre secondaire pour nous arrê er le plus possible sur celles d'intérêt vraiment général.
Ceci dit, passons a l'ordre du jour.

Une proposition du Ministère tendant au remplacement comme membre de droit: de l'Inspecteur du 3me cercle des Irrigations par 'Ingénieur des Batiments de l'Etat est accep: tée. Le motif qu'on allègue pour ce remplacement étant les absences fréquentes de l'Inspecteur des Irrigations, Me Padoa Bey fait seulement remarquer que S.E. le Goưverngur et le Directeur Général des Douanes n'assistent pas plus souvent aux séances, et qu'ils ne sont pas pour cela remplacés.
La question de la location des terrains pour de longues durées est ajournée pour tudes que le Comité du Contentieux doit encore faire sur ce sujet.

La cession a bail d'un terrain à M. Ralli pour la construction d'un casino d une lieu à une interminable discussion. Les uns s'opposent catégoriquement à ce qu'on vote sur ce cas particulier avant d'avoir tranché la question de. principe, à savoir la location de terrains pour de longues durées, tandis que les autres voudraient que, sans trancher cette question de principe, on votât le projet de M. Rulli clumme d'intérêt g néral. La discussion menaçant de s'éterniser, M Rieti demande Ja clôture du débat et la mise aux voix. La concession est repoussée à la majorité, comme n'étant pas d'utilité publique.

Une autre disc ission prèsque aussi longue s'engage au sujet des crédits a accorder pour la réorganisation du service technique. Tout le débat roule au fond sur l'augmentation à accorder à M. Wilner M. l'Administrateur se prévalant de l'urgence pour assurer la bonne marche des services, M Escoffier r clame d'abord un rapport du Comité des Finances et Me. Padoa Bey proteste contre l'urgence "Nos services techniques, dit-il en substance, n'out jamais fonctionné d'une manière remarquable; mais je ne crois pas qu'il guffise de 8 jours pour les désorganiser. Chaque fois qu'il s'agit de questions importantes, on se réclame de l'urgence." M. Salvago propose de voter les crédits demandés, soit L.E 2682 sur la Réserve du Budget ordinaire et L.E. 1620 sur le Budget extraordinaire pour la réorganisation de service technique, et cela sur la proposition de M. l'Administrateur qui, étant mie x place que personne pour connaitre la question, affirme qu'il y a urgence." Mais, comme il existe déjà à cet égard une décision analogue de la Délégatio en date du 26 février 1907, leoture est donnée de cette décision, qui est votée à la majorité, sans en retrancher le dernier paragraphe relatif à M. Wilner. M. Escoffier profite d'un éloge fait de cet employé de la Municipa lité par le Dr. Schiess Pacha pour protester contre les personnalités.

Sur le Budget Extr ordinaire, les crédits suivants sont votés sans discussion et à main levée : L.E 100, pour des essais de f migation avec le gaz Clayton ; L.E. 244 pour la confection et la réparation des voitures d'ambulance; le crédit à allouer pour aménagements provisoires du palais municipal actuel, en attendant la construction du nouvel Hotel de Ville, soit LE 1250 pour l'agrandissement des archives et l'installation d'un cabinet de toilette pour les Conseillers Municipaux, L.E. 1500 pour la construction d'une nouvelle pièce pour les ingenieurg, L. E. 200 pour l'installation d'un ventilateur dans la salle des séances et L.E.800 pour enduits et replatrage, au total L.E. 3800.

Vient ensuite la question relative à la réglementation des poids. M. l'Administrateur refait l'historiq e de cette question qui trafne depuis deux ans et demi. Le Gouvernement qui voulait d'abord q 'on attendit son règlement, n'a encore rien fait et il a laissé entendre à M. l'Administrateur qe si la ville d'Alexandrie etait pressée, elle pouvait inettre en vigueur son propre règlement. Me Padoa Bey fait observer que, M. Bernardi ayant levé tous les obstacles qui s'opposaient à l'entrée des agents de l'ordre publio dans les magasins, rien p't- tait plus tacile ; mais que le gouvernement devait aussi prendre à sa charge tous les procès | qui en résulteraient à l'encontre de la Munici. palité. La Commission vote la mise en vigue ir du règlement q 'elle avait élaboré à ce sujet.
Sur la demande de M. Escoffier, la question des excédents et emprises est renvoyée à la

>prochaine séance. | La proposition de M. le Baron de Menasce au sujet de l'évaluation des ziadeta de tanzim est renvoyée au conseil d'évaluation pour essai. Yebia Pacha proteste vivement contre la proposition.

prochaine séance. | La proposition de M. le Baron de Menasce au sujet de l'évaluation des ziadeta de tanzim est renvoyée au conseil d'évaluation pour essai. Yebia Pacha proteste vivement contre la proposition.

Le Dr. Valensin expose sa proposition de donner le nom de Giosué Carducci à une rue ou place de la ville d'Alexan Arie. Le grand poète italien qui vient de mou ir 4, en effet, composé une ode en l'honneur d'Alexandrie où il prédit de façon pour ainsi dire prophétique aon brillant avenir. N'est-ce pas un titre suffisant pour la reconnaissance des Alexaudrins 1 - Yehia Pacha répond que pour donner suite à une telle proposition il faudrait que G. Carduooi ait a journé dans notre ville on da

moins qu'il lui ait rendu quelque service appréoiable — M. Salvago so rallio avec enthousiastne, à l'idée de M le Dr Valensin et dit que Yehia Pacha peut se tranquilliser sur l'invasion éventuelle des noms de poètes européens dans nos rues. Il est pon de poetes de l'envergure de Carducci et lar 1 tition fréquente de la proposition actuelle n'est pas à craindre. Me Padoa Bey, tout en se ralliant aussi à proposition, regrette qu'un grand français, Pasteur, qui a rendu divers services à Alexandrie n'ait pas le meme honneur. Il espère q e l'oubli gera répars.—- La proposition Valensin est votée, malgré les protestations de plusieurs membres indigènes.
La séance est levée à 7 h. 20.

The game was fast and keen from the outset, the K. S. C. scoring 3 goals the first chukker. The guards then pulled themselves together, one goal only being scored against them in the second chukker. Score : K. S. C., 4 ; Guards, 5 In the third chukker, the guards played up well, improving as they went on. They had bad luck not to score. Major Pereira made several brilliant runs. Within two minutes of time the K. S. C. team scored another goal, bringing the score level, and just as the bell rang they registered another, thus winning an excellent match by one goal. div.head:
IMPERIAL PARLIAMENT
Premier and The Lords
IRISH HOME RULE

div.p: Sir H. Campbell-Bannermån, replying to a memorial of the Radical Members of Parliament, demanding action with reference to the Lords, assures them that no time has been lost, and that the Government, won't disappoint the expectations of its party.

The Duke of Devonshire, addressing a gathering at the Unionist Free-Trade Club, dwelt on the necessity for maintaining the union of the party and opposing Home-Rule even at the risk of Protection.(Reuter)

House of LORDS.--During the Irish debate Lord Crewe assorted that the Government was not disturbed by Mr Balfour's mock heroics. It was impossible to make any statement till the Bill was produced. Lord Loreburn said that he, like Sir A. Campbell-Bannerman, was a Home-Ruler. The Government did not intend to introduce a Home-Rule Bill, but whatever it did, it must inevitably lead to Home-Rule.
An all-night sitting took place in the House of Commons during the discussion on the Army Annual Bill. (Reuter)
76 suffragettes were arrested. (Reuter)

The debate in the Duma developed into a wrangle between the reactionary members and the Socialists. A declaration on behalf of the latter was read accusing the Government with abetting the massacre and asserting that the state of the country was worse than ever. The other parties abstained from entering into the controversy. Ultimately a Constitutional Democratic motion declaring that the result of the elections sufficiently expressed the sentiments of the country, and therefore debate wes unnecessary, was adopted by a large majority. (Reuter)
The alarmist reports are without foundation. Only thirty Cossacks without their horses arrived in order to relieve the guards of the different consulates, (Reuter)
The foreign Residents have written to the Sultan asking him to abolish slavery. (Havas)
The Chamber has passed a motion of M. Jaurès for the appointment of a commission which will examine Mgr. Montagnini's papers. (Havas)
Count Lamsdorff died at San Remo (R)
Count Lamsdorff is dead. (Havas)

Serious agrarian riots have taken place in North Rumania lately. 2,000 peasants entered the town of Botuchrini and plundered and burned the Jewish quarter. In an encounter with troops a number were killed or wounded. The Chambers hare authorized the concentration of troops. (Reuter)

div.head: An American Panic.
div.p: A sudden storm has burst over the Stock Markets here. It had been thought that the continuous fall which had taken place in American railway securities had got rid of the inflation of last Autumn, but America is nothing if not exaggeration, and in view of the magnificent trade which the country has been doing, it would certainly seem as if the fall had been as much over-done as the rise. There are many reasons mentioned on Change for this extraordinary debacle, but the fact that it communicated itself to Consols, gives the idea that it is not purely local, and that there may be other influences in the air which have led to the remarkable collapse which has taken place all-round. Some think that politics are at the bottom of it, but the best-informed seem to regard America and the money situation there was mainly responsible.

It is particularly unfortunate that, at this crisis of events, a new Secretary to the Treasury, whose views are entirely unknown,should be at the helm at Washington, and the relief which he has go far extended, by postponing indefinitely the repayment of 30,000,000 dollars due from the banks, is considered quite inadequate to meet the situation, although there is nothing to show that more relief will not be offered. One thing is certain, and that is that the heavy fall, amounting in some instances to 25 and 30 percent., will largely decrease the amount of money required to carry the large quantity of floating railway securities, and thus the money market ought to be, at any rate, a considerable gainer by this "clear-out." That embarrassment, to a greater or lesser extent, must follow goes without saying, and if we are to believe that the fall in Consols is due to the collapse of the American market, it would point to large sales having been made by English holders to meet the differences on Americans. There would not appear to be any real source of weakness in the positious here, and with trade in its present prosperous condition, there is hardly room for any serious collapse. Indeed, all securities on the list appear to be good investments at present prices.

There is nothing in the Bank position to cause anxiety. The Directors have wisely decided to retain the 5 per cent, rate, which must in the end prove effective in drawing considerably larger supplies of gold, and the banking community are getting to work with a view to increasing reserves.

Even in these "panicky" times, the Japanese loan, of which £11,500,000 was issued in this country, has been a success. Most of the applicants have received only 50 per cent. of what they asked for, and an even larger num. ber of investors came forward in Paris. That such loans can be floated successfully at such a time certainly points to the fact that there is plenty of money to invest if only there was confidence in the value of the securities.

When great events of this kind are moving the small Egyptian market passes unnoticed, and, very naturally, prices are marked down. This does not necessarily mean that any large amount of selling is taking place, but rather is the result of neglect.

div.head: The Bank Return.
div.p: The Bank statemeThe Bank Return.nt this week shows an increase in the reserve of £278,858, to £26,687,756, with an increase in the ratio to liabilities of 1.6 to 46.4 per cent. Twelve months ago the reserve stood at £28,635,278 and the ratio at 47.55 per cent. ' he stock of bullion has decreased by £105,000, which is practically the net eMux of gold abroad. Active note circulation has contracted £348,000, and Public Deposits have increased by £1,251,000, other deposits showing a decrease of £2,653,000 "Other" securities are £1,652,000 lower.

The tone in the Stock Markets to-day has been more cheerful and in several directions there has been some show of recovery. Three more failures are announced, making five in all for yesterday and to-day —but the effect upon markets has been hardly noticeable.

Not for many years has the gilt-edged market been so helpless as during the past week. On Wednesday Consols went below 85, the lowest level touched since they were placed on a 2½ per cent. basis, and this notwithstanding the fact that the Government broker had for some days previous made an average daily purchase of £50,000 of the stock.

Yesterday, it is satisfactory to note, the - market was much steadier and at the close, notwithstanding the great weakness prevalent in other sections, the premier security showed a recovery of 7/16 for cash and for the Account. To-day Consols have registered a further gain of , at 3/16 at 85 ¼ for cash and 85 7/16 for the account.

div.head: Foreign Bonds.
div.p: The foreign market has been irregular and generally weak, but yesterday the market steadied up somewhat, and in several instances substantial advances were noted. Russians were very firm, the Fives gaining ⅝ and the Fours ¼ The ne Japanese issue was a trifle weak at ¼ premium, and the 4½ per cent. (First Series) gave way ⅛, but the First Fours were ¼ better. To-day the market has been quiet. Japanese have given way, but Russians are unchanged.

div.head: Home Rails.
div.p: During the heavy set-back in Americans on Wednesday, the home railway market showed an all-round decline, but yesterday it followed the example of Consols, and after a weak opening, gradually recovered. Brighton "A" were strongly favoured. In the morning they were no better than 96½, but later were bought up to 98. Lancashire & Yorkshire and North British Preferred showed gains of, Hull & Barnsley and North Eastern ¼, and North British Deferred and London, Chatham and Dover ⅛.
The home railway market has been steady to-day. North Western have put on 1, and there are several gains of ¼. South Western Deferred have shed ¾.

div.head: Americans.
div.p: It is 22 years since there was so much excitement in the New York stock markets as during yesterday and Wednesday. Huge quantities of securities have been thrown on the market, not only by weak holders but latterly also by the more important firms who have suffered severely as the result of the slump, and were compelled to throw overboard many of their holdings. Yesterday afternoon a condition of panic reigned in Wall Street. and many brokers lost their heads in their endeavours to sell. Naturally with so much excitement preVailing the stupid rumours which were spread with regard to possible future official action against the railways had the effect of increasing the aların, and although the bears, covering for profit, turned the market sharply, the rally: only lasted about half-an-hour, and was followed by further frantic selling. The day's sales amounted to 2,521,500 shares, which is reported to surpass any previous record on the New York Exchange since the Northern Pacific panic six years ago.

Yesterday morning the tone here was quiet, and under the influence of some buying orders, an improving tendency was noticeable. When the first advices came over from Wall Street, however, a further relapse set in, and in the Street the market was demoralised, and prices fell away heavily without check.

Union Pacific, which closed in the House at 148, went down to 129, Southern Pacifica dropped: 10 points to 72, and then rallied to 76, and in nearly every case severe losses were recorded at the close.

Americans have again occupied a good deal of attention to-day The earlier quotations followed pretty closely yesterday's movements in Wall Street, but there has since been some recovery. Unions at 136½ show a loss of 12¾ ; Reading have dropped 6 to 53, and Southern Pacific 3 / to 79xd, Aitchison and Milwaukee 3, Canadian Pacific 2¼, and Illinois Central 2.

The Egyptian market is still very quiet, and shows no improvement on last week. In fact, there is not a bargain doing, but this is not to be wondered at considering the state of markets in general, and the American market in particular

Daira Ordinary, after starting at 15½, rose quickly to 16, but closed 15⅝ -⅞, while the Deferred are round about 90. National Bank of Egypt have been better at 27, but leave off at 27¼. Agricultural Bauk were yesterday up to 9 1/16. They are now lower at 8 15/16. Agricultural Preference are quoted 9 ⅝-¾ and the Debentures 90 1. Egyptian Estates are dull at a tot and Corporation of Western Egypt were at one time as flat as ⅝, but gloss better again at Delta Land and Investment are quiterat and Delta Preference at 11-4. Union Foncière are 6, and Land Bank of Egypt at 9. Egyptian Investment and Agency have been enquired about, but no business has resulted, and they are quoted ¼-½ premium. Land and General Trust close at 1/16 - 2/16 premium, with buyers about at prontium. Khedivial Mail Ordinary are nominally 1¼-½, and the Preference 4½-¾. Bank of Roumania close 9½-10 with no business passing in them.

There is not very much business doing in mining shares, but, compared with other sections of the house, the tone is distinctly cheerful. During the past two days the Continent has resumed buying Kaffirs, and this has helped to keep the market steady. Yesterday several of the leading speculative favourites showed substantial gains, Rand Mines and East Rand finishing 7/32 up. Gold Field and Modders registered an advance of & The tone for Kaltirs has not been so favourable to day. East Rands have lost 3 32, and Rand Mines to the closing prices for these being 1/16 and 6 ⅞.
In the Egyptian mining market shares have been flat. Egyptian Mines Exploration have given way 1s 3d. to 1s. 9d., and Nile Valley 6d. to 3s. 6d.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, In a spirit of fair play to all, to perroit - within certain necessary limits - free discussion.

div.head: - THE ENGLISH IN EGYPT.
To the EDITOR OF THE "Egyptian Gazette "
div.p: Sir,--I was surprised to see that the few observations made by me on this subject in answer to a letter signed "G.J.S.," which you kindly published, have resulted in provoking an unnecessary and uncalled-for defence of Orientals. I do not remember having said in my letter anything against Orientals or which could hurt the feelings of such, for, to make the simple statement that the composition of oriental dishes is unknown to Englishmen is neither an insult to Orientals nor a deprecation of their cuisine. That latter is most excellent I have no doubt whatever ; at the same time, it is not the food to which an Englishman has been brought up : not knowing it, he does not appreciate it perhaps sufficiently well. Again, I am not aware of having suggested that oriental manners are bad. On the contrary, we all know that a real oriental gentleman is the pink of politeness, kindness, and hospitality. In fact, oriental manners are 80 perfect that it is with a certain amount of regret that one sees them being gradually adulterated by the introduction of European manners and ways. At the same time thúy are not the manners of an Englishman. I do not for one moment wish to insinuate that English manners are the best ; this they may not be ; but who are we that we should arrogate to ourselves the right to change the English character 7 For my part, I do not think that the endeavours of "G.J.S.," or of anyone else for that matter, will meet with much success in this direction. Again, I have never said that Orientals are not intelligent, or that Christianity did not rise in the Levant or was not spread by Orientals. I am afraid t at "G.J.S." is again wandering hopelessly from the point. His original argument was that the English are hated by the people over whom they rule on account of their unsociability. In my first letter I endeavoured to show that this not the case Now, the only fresh argument put forward by "G.J.S." in favour of his contention is the I quoted opinion of an unknown English news paper writer published in an English paper, and primarily intended for the edification of his own people. We all know that people, in their zeal to outshine other nations, will frequently find fault with themselves and their own institutions, very often even when no fault exists, and this tendency is more frequent with the English than with any other race. But is it safe for a foreigner to take for granted this exaggerated national abuse ? Is it fair ? Does it not look like hitting a man below the belt ? Now, as to the real question at issue. What is it that "G.J.S." wishes the English to do in order to become popular with the Egyptians and to gain their affection ? As I understand, he desires that the English should cultivate native society to a greater extent, by frequenting their salons and clubs, by encouraging the native to frequent their houses, and by choosing their friends and acquaintance among them. If this is what he wants, he should know (since he is 90 well acquainted with the Eilish character) that the life of an English official in Egypt would not be worth living. Let the Englishman do as "G.J.S." would have him do, and he will not only be hated but despised into the bargain. We may, I think, take the Turks as a-fair example of "G.J.S.'s" policy. During their administration of Egypt, were they loved ? If history can be credited they were not even respected, and according to "G.J.S." the English are hated only.

The principal reason why the Turks were not liked by the Egyptians were that they were not Arabs and next that they were not firm, just, or impartial. In the case of the English their very aloofness encourages the equalities Away from dangerous friendships and temptations, away from intrigues and party disputes, their attitude as rulers of Egypt commands naught but respect and obedience. The French in Tunis and the Austrians in Herzegovina keep themselves as much aloof from the population as their national character permits, but with the English the task is much easier on account of the peculiarities of their national training and character

It appears to me that the remarks of "G.J.S." are intended to apply mainly to the English Government official. This being so I will not go out of my way to take up the judgels on behalf of the more civilian. It will be apparent to any fair-minded leader that observations such as those quoted from an English paper apply to a certain class of Englishmen with whom we have all of us at times come in contact, and I think it will be admitted with this clagg the average official has but little in common Moreover I fail to understand how the behaviour or deportment of any individual Englishman can influence the degree of affection or of disaffection with which his race is regarded by the Egyptians or, for that matter, any other subject people.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Mr. Haldane says that the annual cost of the army in Egypt to the British taxpayer is £170,000 approximately, exclusive of the cost of transporting the troops.
Lieutenant M. G, Dill, Royal Army Medical Corps, has been seconded for- service with the Egyptian Army in the usual course.

To-day, the Assaye left Southampton for Bombay on her last trip eastwards. This practically closes the trooping season of 1906-07. This trip of the Assays is an additional, and she carries about 900 soldiers, including the representatives of all arms of the service.
Vice Admiral Sir C. C. Drury bag been for. mally appointed to the command of the Mediterranean Fleet, with the rank of acting admiral.

It is stated that, Sir Percy Scott, Director of Gunnery, has some new wrinkles for the Mediterranean Fleet, whither he has just gone from England. It is further said that his improvements will lead to a further stride not only in naval gunnery but in land gunnery.

The army estimates show that the British Army of Occupation in Egypt will be maintained at a strength of 5,726 of all ranks, composed as follows —one regiment of cavalry, 655 ; one battery of R.H A. and one company of R.G.A., 315; one company Royal Engineers, 108 ; three battalions and seven companies of infantry (exclusive of the 3rd Battalion Coldstream Guards), 3,626 ; one company Army Service Corps, 95 ; one company Royal Army Medical Corps, 120 ; detachment of Army Ordnance, 52; detachment of Army Veterinary Corps, 9-total, 5,726. The contribution from the Khedive's Government towards the maintenance of this force has been increased from £100,000 to £150,000.

Captain and Brevet Major C, F, Romer, N tal duty from the appointment of D.A.Q.M.G. on the General Staff at Headquarters, has been posted to the 2nd Battalion at Fermoy, where he will take up duty on the 28th inst.

Lieutenant V C, Calry, from the Northumberland Fusiliers, has been transferred to the 6th Inniskilling Dragoons, to fill the vacancy caused by the promotion of Captain Holland. The new Inniskilling officer served in the "Fighting Fifth" since January, 1902.
- It is intimated that Lieutenant C.K. Hut. chinson, Coldstream Guards, will retain the appointment of Superintendent of Gymnasia, London, for another year.

Lieutenant Halfpenny, Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, has been seconded for service with the West Africa' Rifles, in which he previously served with distinction. He is a born soldier, who has risen from the ranks by sbeer merit, and physically one of the finest officers in the service.
Second Lieutenant W.A. Douglas, 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, Cairo, has resigned his commission, to which he was appointed a year ago.

This week has been a most uninteresting and featureless one, prices moving a few points p or down according to the orders which may be in the Market at the time either to buy or sell, and emanating, it is said, from foreign sources The tendency is for lower prices notwithstanding the bullish cables sent from New Orleans, and from Mr. Price at New York. div.p: The new 18-knot twin Borew S.S. 'Osmanieh, leaving Alexandria on the 28th March, will follow a special fast itinerary, reaching Piraeus (Athens) in 30 hours, Smyrna in 74 hours, and Constantinople in 24 hours, in connection with the Oriental Railway's daily express service for Vienna, Berlin, Paris and London.
Special arrangements will be made for part of the 7.30 a.m. Express train from Cairo to run direct alongside,

Ravan, propriétaire de l'"Express-Publicité", est seul éditeur du "Guide-Horaire" de l'Egypte et du Soudar fourni officiellement par l'Administration des Chemins de fer. La quatrième édition du "Guide-Horaire" actuellement en préparation, paraltra le 1er Mai 1907. Le Guide Horaire" est un précieux intermédiaire de publicité méritant une attention toute particulière de la part des Banques, de l'industrie et du Commerce en général, à cause des avaritages incontestables qu'il offre sur les publications similaires, Mr. Jules Mignot, Directeur et Agent Général de l' "Express-Publicité", a seul qualité de traiter pour les insertions dans le "Guide-Horaire qui ne sont payables qu'après publica. tion et contre justificatif. 29701-10A-3

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demio.) L'animation est localisée aux Nile Land qui s'avancent a 30 1/2, Ritz à 3 1/8, Estates à 2 3/32, United à 1 1/8 et Nungovich à 29 1/8. On traite la Gabbari Land entre 9 et 10 livres Bonne demande sur l'Union Foncière à 5 15/16 6. Mieux tenues également la Land Bank à 8 3/4, la Béhéra à 39 1/2, et l'Aboukir a 40/6. Mais les autres fluctuations indiquent toutes un nouveau recal, avec affaires d'ailleurs clairsermées. Parmi les gros titres, l'Agricole fléchiteà 8 15/16, la National Bank · 26 13/16, l'Alexandria Water à 13 1/8, les Jouissances Eaux du Caire a 273, la Daïra à 15 7/8, la Privil giée Bière d'Alexandrie à 223, la Cassa di Sconto à 233 1/2, 230 pt 218, le Comptoir à 6 7/8 l'aneienne et 6 5/8 la nouvelle, et la Banque d'Orient à 129. L'Anglo Egyptian Land Allotment dont nous annonçons la prochaine assemblée générale est un peu mieux tenue, l'action à 8 1/8 et la fondateur à P.T. 100, sans vendeurs. . L'Arditi .et la Levico se maintiennent aux mêmes cours que précédemment:* . Les Privilégiées Tramways s'avancent à 184, tandis que les Dividendes faiblissent à 330. Les Markets fléchissent à 25/6 et la Levant A 7/8, tandis que la Salt and Soda rem inte a 21. La tendance générale est toujours indécise, Ja bourse de Londres continuant à donner le mauvais exemple.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS.
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them Bre fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, aid possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than any other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to On leaving Egypt is Sicily. Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio Rubattino Co's steamers, which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMINA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is m chto interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic renmates that are found all over the island, are an endless source of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in BC 212, when Archimedes was slain--his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pas au temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city he Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Erimiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria, every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay-Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento (you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where all other week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excurssions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade. In Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallum brosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from. Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cogwheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO, One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY.
GENOA (La Superba).
div.p: - The most I picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities, and a phenomenally equable temperature- warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble calumns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santa filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and-a-half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on as count of its thermal springs, change trains at Bergo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P. & 0. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste-Vienna express from Alexandria As regarde heavy legge, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and
The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Vilan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass & quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at. every turn. The approach the Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other seaport. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon. Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes. COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in olie-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza: Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting CERNOBBIO is a charming spot.; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio- opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs." LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como, and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Aro nd it rise M San Salvatore, M. de Caprino and M. Generoso. LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate, and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and "The Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion. LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps. In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous. The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg ner ding a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature. BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse. THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds ; just the place to rest and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concerts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc. "THE BERNESE OBERLAND.— INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort, and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaker is also not får from the famous" waterfalls, Gieselbach. Trummelbach and Staubbach Then also the glaciers of (Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed. CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft. above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, suarounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter. ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe. Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully situated on the lake of Zurich Theatres." Big Concert Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The National Museum

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and Russian Steam Navigation Co. If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter. Tuesday festival held at Megara. for which a special train is run from Athens. It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery There is also good snipe and quaıl shooting to be had.

div.head: LAKE of LUCERNE
Palace & Grand Hotel Axen-Fels. WORLD WIDE REPUTATION.
div.p: The Leading Hotel for English and American families. Electric Railway from Brunnen to Axen-Fels. The magnificent Park and Woods have nearly a mile frontage on the Lake. Best Spring Resort. 2200 feet above the Sea, Every Comfort, level Wooded Walks.

mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay. These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry boats," having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

BAGNI LIDO (Venice) The most important bathing station in Italy. Café-Restaurant and terrace on the sea. Hydrotherapie Institute. Concerts daily. Frequented by the highest classes of society.
GRAND HOTEL DES BAINS. Adjoining the sea. First-class hotel with dependencies & Chalets. 2 rooms & saloons. Electric light aqueduct. Every modern comfort. Delightful residence, without any mosquitos.

THE GRAND HOTEL, LIDO. Hotel with its dependencies (Swiss Hotel), in the most delightful situation of the Lido at the landing place, five minutes', walk from the bathing place. Wonderful view of the legune of Venice. Room Iron 3 lire, with board from 8.50 per day. No mosquitos. Very dry and safe air.
Address -- SOCIETE BAGNI, LIDO, VENICE, ITALY.
